Simulations of multilevel models (Maas & Hox, 2004, 2005) show that sample sizes of 50 or fewer at higher levels produced biased estimates of standard errors. Bickel (2007, pp. 282-283) raises doubts about whether 50 observations at the higher levels of analysis produces sufficient statistical power. Thus, even if we had used National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP) data from all 50 states, the statistical issues of calculating a three-level model would not be resolved. In addition, however, many states do not have sufficient numbers of English language learner (ELL) students to warrant inclusion in the analysis on substantive grounds.

Several of the Level 2 variables provided by NAEP had significant numbers of missing cases. The professional development for diversity variable, mean years of teaching experience, and school enrollment category variables had approximately 4% to 8% missing values (across years and ELL status groups) for students, representing 1% to 4% of schools. For these variables, we substituted the school-level mean. The percent lunch program eligible variable was missing for a larger proportion of cases, about 9% to 10% of students from 7% to 10% of schools. As this variable is intended to control for the contextual socioeconomic effect, to estimate values for missing cases, we calculated mean home resources and regressed school-level percent lunch program on mean home resources. We used the resulting regression equation (adjusted R2 of approximately .32 to .33) to estimate values for percent lunch program eligibility. Note that attending to missing values at the school level is especially important because for any missing value at a school, HLM techniques would drop all of the student responses from that school from the analysis, compromising the representativeness of the sample.

Eligibility for the federal Title I program is another possible indicator of socioeconomic status. It was available as a student-level measure for 2005, but not 2007, so we did not include it in the final analyses. The National Center for Education Statistics recognizes that better indicators of socioeconomic status are needed and has commissioned investigations regarding efficient means to collect information that is more precise on student socioeconomic status (National Center for Education Statistics, 2009a).

Models were also estimated with random effects of all key Level 2 independent variables. These models did not provide a better fit than those reported here. In addition, we estimated cross-level interaction effects of bilingual emphasis and all student-level control variables. None of these cross-effects were statistically significant.

Lubienski and Lubienski (2006) use this guideline in their interpretation of NAEP mathematics scores. National reading achievement means in 2005 and 2007 are 42 to 43 points higher for eighth graders than for fourth graders, leading to a rough guide of about 10 points per grade level (as calculated at http://nces.ed.gov/nationsreportcard/naepdata/). In this situation, a fourth grader who scores 10 points lower than the fourth-grade average score is approximately 1 year behind in his or her knowledge of the fourth-grade material being tested. Moreover, given that learning growth is largest in the early grades, and decelerates across grades, the number of scale score points between grades are different (i.e., larger in the earlier grades and smaller in the later grades). The authors are grateful to an anonymous reviewer for clarifying this point.

By including the bilingual education emphasis variable in these models, we are implicitly assuming that the intervals between values are equal and thus that the effect on reading achievement is linear. We conducted checks for nonlinearity by rerunning the models with a dummy variable for schools in sheltered/structured English immersion (SEI) states (Arizona and California, coded as 1) versus schools in the other six states that have moderate to high bilingual emphasis (coded as 0).

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Francesca López is an assistant professor in the Educational Policy and Leadership department at Marquette University. Prior to earning her PhD in educational psychology from the University of Arizona, she was a bilingual elementary teacher and at-risk high school counselor. Her research is focused on understanding how school contexts promote achievement for Latino students—particularly those for whom English is a second language.

Elizabeth McEneaney is an assistant professor of education at UMass–Amherst. A former high school mathematics teacher, she earned a PhD in sociology from Stanford University. Her research interests include language acquisition policy, particularly as applied in STEM fields, and the organizational aspects of the charter school movement.
